newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: FOCUS - Rotterdam oil giants remodel refineries.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Rotterdam oil giants remodel refineries.

text.p: As an axe continues to hang over much of Europe's excess oil refining capacity, Rotterdam's oil giants have remodelled their plants to face the millennium.
Royal Dutch/Shell's started up the 3.3 billion guilder ($1.7 billion) "PER+" upgrade at its 374,000 barrels per day (bpd) capacity Pernis plant this month.

Within a year, one of the two refineries owned by rival Nerefco -- a BP/Texaco joint venture -- will close, but most of the capacity will remain after a massive upgrade of its nearby Europoort plant, at around a tenth of the cost of Shell's project.
Both plans are a reaction to declining profits from European refining, the result of overcapacity and a product mix ill-suited to current demand.
The investments acknowledge the increasing market share of diesel.
Shell predicts that by 2005, diesel demand in Europe, at about 125 million tonnes, will for the first time outstrip that for gasoline.
The measures are also designed to address tougher EU environmental legislation.
A European Commission proposal recommends reducing the level of sulphur in diesel from the current 500 parts per million (ppm) to 350 ppm by the year 2000.
Shell's plan will also cut the output of less profitable fuel oil, used for power generation, by 40 percent.
"In however many years time, refineries will have a product (fuel oil) which has next to no value. Shell is acting now," said David Stedman head of research at Daiwa Europe.

Shell's "PER+" complex adds three units to the existing Pernis refinery -- a new hydrocracker, the largest of its kind in the world, a gasification unit to produce hydrogen and a 115 megawatt (MW) power plant.
The refinery may end up transmitting up to 80 MW to the public grid, making it one of the first refineries to be a net seller of electricity.
Shell is keen to trumpet the environmental benefits of its investment.
The new units will result in the recovery of almost three times as much sulphur as before and nitrogen oxide emissions will be cut be around 40 percent.
More carbon dioxide will also be collected, leading to talk of underground storage of the gas or use in greenhouses by the horticultural industry.

"We have set ourselves the goal of becoming one of the top 10 refineries in the world in 1998 in terms of management and efficiency," said Govert Boeles, director of personnel and social affairs at Shell Pernis.
The Per+ complex will be fully operational in the early autumn.
Nerefco's plans are less grandiose.
By the end of this year, the company's 220,000 bpd capacity Pernis refinery will be reduced to a single hydrofiner, a unit for sulphur removal, and that too will wind down in autumn 1998.
Most of the loss will be made up by the expansion at Europoort. Its 200,000 bpd capacity will double with the upgrading of a currently disused central distillation unit due to start up in November.
Output of diesel will also rise after the completion of a new 40,000 bpd hydrofiner at Europoort, to replace the 25,000 bpd unit in Pernis.
The result will be more middle distillate and chemical feedstock naphtha and less gasoline and fuel oil and lower levels of sulphur.
"It's fairly clear that Nerefco's changes are better suited (than Shell's) to market conditions of low returns," said Jeremy Hudson, energy analyst at Salomon Brothers in London.
Dutch refineries may have been forced to the forefront of change because of their dominant role in export and international spot markets.
Shell's Pernis refinery exports two-thirds of its annual output of 17.9 million tonnes.
Return on downstream investments will remain poor while western Europe's overcapacity persists, analysts say.
West European refinery output is expected to fall by 300,000 bpd over the next two years.
